entry.et: Middle English, from Old English sūth; akin to Old High German sund- south and probably to Old English sunne sun

def.dt: :to, toward, or in the south a house facing south
:into a state of decline or ruin causes the sluggish economy to go south G. F. Will
:situated toward or at the south the south entrance
:coming from the south a south wind
:the direction of the south terrestrial pole :the direction to the right of one facing east
:the compass point directly opposite to north
:regions or countries lying to the south of a specified or implied point of orientation
:the southeastern part of the United States
:the right side of a church looking toward the altar from the nave
:the one of four positions at 90-degree intervals that lies to the south or at the bottom of a diagram
:a person (as a bridge player) occupying this position in the course of a specified activity
:the declarer in bridge
:the developing nations of the world :third world 3 compare north 2b
Robert 1634–1716 Eng. clergyman
:a native or inhabitant of the Republic of South Africa
:afrikaner
:a compass point that is one point east of due south :S11°15′E
:a compass point that is one point west of due south :S11°15′W
:any of a breed of large red cattle of English origin formerly bred for both milk and meat but now increasingly specialized for beef production
:the southernmost point of the earth
:the zenith of the heavens as viewed from the south terrestrial pole
:the pole that points toward the south
:south pole 2
